Department of Energy and Power Engineering Henan University of Science and Technology Luoyang 471003 China In the study, based on the purpose of efficient catalytic AB for hydrogen production, the photochemical properties influence of metal(Ru, Ni) and nonmetal(B,P) elements doping on the g-C3N4 are studied systematacially. The design method of high performance bifunctional catalyst of photocatalysis and metal catalysis are provided. The results have proved that both non-metals B, P and metal Ru, Ni have an efficient regulatory effect on the band structure of g-C3N4, which make the band gap of the clean monolayer g-C3N4(001) decrease from 1.175 eV to 0.261eV(B-g-C3N4(001)) and 0.671eV(P-g-C3N4(001)), 0.164 eV(Ni-g-C3N4(001)) and 0.260 eV(Ru-g-C3N4(001)), respectively. B element have the better modification effect compared with the P element. The reduction of band gap is attributed to the electronic orbit modification effect of impurity element B, P, Ni, Ru in g-C3N4. Ru metal doped g-C3N4 is reduces the barrier of OH bond breakage of CH3OH(reduced from 4.551 eV to 1.530 eV), which is beneficial to the hydrogen-producing reaction of AB alcoholysis. The construction and design of a new bifunctional catalyst(photocatalysis and metal catalysis) RuNiB@g-C3N4 is an efficient route in catalyze AB for hydrogen production. The process of molecule NH3BH3, CH3OH and H2O adsorbed on the B-g-C3N4 are exothermic process, the adsorption energy are -1.562 eV, -1.392 eV and -1.443 eV, respectively. AB is preferentially adsorbed on the B-g-C3N4 catalyst, increasing the adsorption energy of CH3OH and H2O on B-g-C3N4-based catalysts is beneficial to the hydrogen production from AB. The study provides a theoretical method for the research on the technology of the coupling of metal catalysis/photocatalysis ammonia borane to produce hydrogen. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Photochemical property g-C3N4 Hydrogen production Density functional theory Data availability The data that has been used is confidential. 1 Introduction In the process of energy utilization, the energy transformation from traditional fossil energy to advanced clean energy is the trend of energy utilization development [1–3]. It is of extraordinary importance to develop clean and renewable energy, especially green hydrogen energy [4,5]. The photocatalytic hydrogen generation by water splitting using photocatalyst was first reported in 1972 [6]. From then on, photocatalytic hydrogen production technology has gradually become a research hotspot, and researchers have done a lot of work to break through the bottleneck of photocatalytic efficiency. A series of photocatalysts have been synthesized, such as TiO2, bismuth catalyst (Bi3VO4, Bi2O3), SnO2, SiC, g-C3N4 [7–9]. Among them, g-C3N4 has attracted the attention of researchers because of its special layered structure and superior photochemical properties. Graphitic carbon nitride (g-C3N4) is treated as a most promising photocatalytic material due to its suitable band structure, broadband spectrum absorption capacity, simple preparation method, low price and excellent catalytic performance. The g-C3N4 has the π-conjugated molecular structure, the suitable band gap with the light absorption wavelength to around 450 nm, which showing a good ability of visible-light response, the longest response wavelength can reach to the blue spectrum [10,11]. In addition, g-C3N4 has superior performance of photocatalytic hydrogen production and organic pollutants treatment, and if its surface is treated with functionalization(for example, cyano-rich g-C3N4), which can improve the light absorption , increase the polarization rate and active site concentration, and promote oxygen activation ability [12]. Gradually, researchers are increasingly looking at it as a solution to environmental pollution and carbon emissions, in particular, the research density in the field of photocatalytic catalyst for hydrogen production is increasing [13,14]. Generally, the photocatalytic performance of pure photocatalyst is relatively poor. Researchers generally modify photocatalysts to improve their photocatalytic performance, including metal ion doping, precious metals deposition, construction of heterojunction, and so on. Among them, element doping (metallic or nonmetallic elements) is the most effective and convenient way to improve photocatalytic performance. The doping dissimilar elements can introduce doping levels between valence band (VB) and conduction band (CB) of the semiconductor catalyst, which reduce the band gap of semiconductor photocatalyst, enhance the photoresponse ability and promote the transfer of photogenerated charge carriers, thereby improving the photocatalytic activity of semiconductor photocatalyst. The doped metal element will form a doping level below the conduction band, and the doped nonmetal element will form a doping level above the valence band to form a doping level. The doping metallic element mainly includes Fe, Cu, Co, Ni, Al, etc., while the doping nonmetallic element includes C, N, S and halogen elements (F, Cl, Br, I), etc. [15,16]. Fig. 1 depicts how the band structure of semiconductor catalysts is affected by metal and non-metal doping. Ahmad et al. [17] prepared Al-ZnO by doping aluminum in zinc oxide with five times more photocatalytic activity than pure zinc oxide. Guo et al. [18] doped N element in g-C3N4 to improve its photocatalytic performance, and found that N-modified porous g-C3N4 nanosheets improved the catalytic performance of hydrogen production in water-splitting reaction. However, the effect of metal and non-metal doping on the photocatalytic properties of the photocatalysts g-C3N4 has not been systematically studied, it is not clear which elements promote its photocatalytic performance. In addition, there are few studies on the mechanism of improving photocatalytic performance of photocatalysts by using DFT method systematically, while the DFT method has advantages in analyzing the photocatalytic mechanism of photocatalysts, it plays a key supplementary role to the experimental method. In this study, the effects of doping of different metals and non-metals on the band structure and photochemical properties of photocatalysts g-C3N4 are systematically investigated. The adsorption effect of doped photocatalyst on ammonia borane(NH3BH3, AB) and alcohol molecules is investigated, the reaction pathway for hydrogen production from alcoholysis of AB is simulated. Ultimately, this study provides a theoretical basis for future research on the technology of photocatalytic ammonia borane to produce hydrogen. Meanwhile, a coupled metal catalyzed/photocatalytic approach is proposed to enhance AB hydrolysis and alcoholysis to hydrogen reaction. 2 Computational details The study is mainly conducted through the method of density functional theory (DFT) calculation, which embraced in CASTEP program package. The GGA -PBE exchange-correlation functional is adopted. The calculation parameters and convergence criteria are refer to the previous literature published by the author [19]. Before the formal calculation, the rationality of the parameter setting is verified, the structural parameters of the g-C3N4 crystal unit cell is calculated using the parameter settings described above, and the calculated results are shown in Fig. 2 , the results of bond length is consistent of previous reported literature [16,20]. The parameter settings in this computational process are acceptable. In the study, the adsorption energy (Eads) is used to characterize the ease of contact between reactants and catalysts in chemical reactions, Eads is computed as the Eq. (1). For example, the H2O or CH3OH and AB molecule adsorbed on semiconductor catalyst g-C3N4 (001) can be described the bond strength between g-C3N4 (001) and H2O or AB molecule [21]. The Ecatalyst and Ecluster refer to the energy of species above after structure optimization. Etotal refer to the total energy of AB or H2O absorbed on the g-C3N4 (001). (1) E a d s = ( E c a t a l y s t + E c l u s t e r ) − E t o t a l 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Nonmetallic element doping of the g-C3N4 As well known, the nonmetallic doping can regulate the band structure and photochemical properties of photocatalysts. In order to investigate the response of photocatalyst g-C3N4 to nonmetallic element doping, the nonmetal P, B are adopted to modify photocatalyst g-C3N4, and improve its photocatalytic performance. In addition, two typical doping sites are selected for comparative study, which are the C3 and N3 sites of carbon and nitrogen atoms, respectively. Electron density difference is an important indicator, which always refers to the electrons transfer from the outer layers of atoms in a molecule compared with the original isolated atom, and can reflect the electrons redistribution when new chemical forces are created. Fig. 3 and Fig. 4 depict the electron differential density of g-C3N4 doped with B element and P, respectively. As the Fig. 3(a) shown, the C and N sites that pure g-C3N4 can be doped to substitute are labeled C1, C2, C3 and N1, N2, N3, respectively. Fig. 3(b), (c) depicts the electron differential density of C3 and N3 sites are substituted by the B atom. As can be seen from the figure, no matter which site the B atom is doped to, it can form a chemical bond force with the surrounding atoms. When B atoms are doped to the N3 site, the outer electrons of the surrounding B atom are moving to C atom, since the two atoms have the sizable force on the outer electrons, only a small number of outer electrons of the B atom can move to the electron orbitals of the C atom, when B atoms are doped to the C3 site, the electron differential density shows a similar pattern, B atom can form a strong force with the surrounding atoms at different doping sites(C3 and N3). When P atoms are doped to the N3 and C3 site, the direction in which the electrons move is somewhat similar, the outer electrons of the P atom are close to the surrounding N and C atom, the electron density around the N and C atoms increases significantly. In addition, the doping of B and P heteroatoms to modulate the electronic structures of C and N atoms in g-C3N4, which contributes to the enhancement of the photoresponsive properties of the catalyst g-C3N4. Table 1 describes the quantitative effects of nonmetallic doping on the electronic and molecular structure of the catalyst g-C3N4. As the Table 1 shown, when the B atom substitute the nitrogen atom at the N3 site, the atom charge of the surrounding atom(C1,C2,C3,N1,N2, B) are 0.45 e, 0.09 e, 0.09 e, −0.33 e, −0.33 e, 0.48 e, respectively, the atom charge of B atom has a positive charge, it means B atom acts as electron donor between the surrounding atoms with the atomic charge of +0.48 e, while the remaining N atom still act as electron acceptor between the surrounding atoms with the atomic charge of −0.33 e. When the B atom substitute the carbon atom at the C3 site, the atom charge of the surrounding atom(C1,C2, B, N1,N2, N3) are 0.46 e, 0.49 e, 0.98 e, −0.56 e, −0.39 e, −0.50 e, respectively, the atom charge of B atom has a positive charge, which indicates the B atom is more likely to lose electrons compared with the C and N, and is a good electron donor. The bond length of the B-C and B-N are 1.481 Å and 1.456 Å, which is longer than the bond length of the CN, this indicates that B-C, B-N bond has a covalent character, but the bond strength is weaker than the original CN of the g-C3N4. When the P atom substitute the nitrogen atom or carbon atom at the N3 site or C3 site, the atom charge are 1.23 e and 2.11e, respectively, the P atom performs a similar function to the B atom, which act as electron donor. In summary, both the electron differential density (Figs. 3, 4) and atom charge states (Table 1) reveal that non-metals B and P are the best electron contributors, which can also effectively regulate the band structure and photochemical properties of photocatalyst g-C3N4. For a semiconductor catalyst, the band gap width determines its response to different wavelengths of light, DOS and PDOS can reveal the mechanism of band gap [22]. In the study, the band structure and density of states (DOS) of the clean g-C3N4 are calculated by DFT, as shown in Fig. 5 . The calculation results show that the clean g-C3N4 (monolayer g-C3N4 (001)) has a band gap of 1.175 eV, and DOS indicates that no electrons are present in the energy range of 0∼1.17 eV. For the B, P doping monolayer g-C3N4 (001), the electron distribution increases obviously around 0 eV to 1.17 eV compared with the pure g-C3N4. To Further explore the mechanism of increased electron distribution, we calculated the Partial Density of States (PDOS) of B-g-C3N4 and P-g-C3N4. As shown in PDOS spectra, the band gap is obviously reduced, from 1.175 eV reduced to 0.261 eV and 0.671 eV, respectively. It shows that non-metals B, P have an efficient regulatory effect on the band structure of g-C3N4, and it also shows that the doping of electron orbitals of B and P can partly explain the band gap decrease of g-C3N4. Fig. 6 (b) and 6(d) depict the PDOS of the B and P doping monolayer g-C3N4(001). In general, the VB energy levels move to higher energies while the CB energy levels move to lower energies, which leads to a decrease in the band gap, and this rule also applies to the non-metallic doped g-C3N4 (001). Specifically, the B-2p, B-2 s electron orbitals and the P-2p, P-2 s electron orbitals all contribute to the orbital hybridization of g-C3N4 at energy levels from 0 eV to 1.17 eV. The above analysis shows that doping B and P elements in g-C3N4 can reduce the band gap width. In order to further elucidate the influence of B, P doping on g-C3N4, the optical absorption of the g-C3N4(001), B-g-C3N4(001) and P-g-C3N4(001) are conducted. As shown in Fig. 7 , the above three photocatalysts exhibit obvious absorption peaks in the wavelength range of 250–500 nm. In addition, it can be seen that the absorption intensity of B-doped and P-doped g-C3N4 is stronger among the three photocatalysts. In the wavelength range of 300 to 400 nm, the doping of B and P effectively improve the light absorption efficiency of g-C3N4. While the wavelength is greater than 750 nm, the light absorption intensity of the pure g-C3N4 and P-doped g-C3N4 is zero, while the B-doped g-C3N4 still maintains a good absorption capacity for longer wavelengths of light, even in the infrared band, it still has a certain response ability. In conclusion, B is a good modifier, which has a good ability to regulate the photoresponse of g-C3N4. 3.2 Metallic element doping of the g-C3N4 For the purpose of investigating the modifying effects of semiconductor catalysts g-C3N4 by metal elements, the transition metal Ni and precious metal Ru are adopted to dope the g-C3N4 via the methods of molecular modeling and DFT calculation. Fig. 8 shows the electron differential density cloud image of g-C3N4 doped with Ni and Ru element. Fig. 8(a), (b) depict electron cloud image of Ni-doped N3 and C3 sites of photocatalyst g-C3N4. As it shown, no matter which site the Ni atom is doped to, it can form a chemical bond force and produce strong intermolecular forces with the surrounding atoms. When Ni atom are doped to the N3 site, the outer electrons of the Ni atom are close to the surrounding C atom, which tend to move to the electron orbitals of the surrounding C atom. When Ni atoms are doped to the C3 site, the electron differential density shows a similar pattern, Ni atom form a strong force with the surrounding atoms at different doping sites (C3 and N3). Fig. 8(c),(d) depict electron cloud image of Ru-doped N3 and C3 sites of photocatalyst g-C3N4, the results also show the outer electron of Ru atom are transferred to the surrounding C or N atoms. In conclusion, metal-doped semiconductor catalyst g-C3N4, the electrons of the metal atom are transferred to the non-metal atom C or N due to the metallic properties of the metal atom. Electron doping of metal atoms to atoms in g-C3N4, which helps to regulate and optimize the band structure of semiconductor catalyst g-C3N4. Table 2 describes the quantitative effects of metallic doping on the electronic and molecular structure of the catalyst g-C3N4. As Table 2 shown, when the Ni atom substitute the nitrogen atom at the N3 site, the atom charge of the surrounding atom (C1, C2, C3, N1, N2, Ni) are 0.37e, 0.01e, 0.01e, −0.35 e, −0.35 e, 1.31 e, respectively, Ni atom acts as electron donor with atom charge of +1.31 e, the remaining N atom still act as electron acceptor with atomic charge of −0.35 e. When the B atom substitute the carbon atom at the C3 site, the atom charge of the surrounding atom (C1, C2, Ni, N1, N2, N3) are 0.41 e, 0.45 e, 1.09 e, −0.499 e, −0.37 e, −0.49 e, respectively, the Ni atom still has a positive charge, which indicates the Ni atom is a good electron donor, and more likely to lose electrons compared with the C and N atom. In addition, the bond length of the Ni-C and Ni-N are 1.747 Å and 1.850 Å, , which indicates that B-C, B-N bond has a covalent character, the bond length of Ni-C, Ni-N bond is longer than the CN, the bond strength is weaker than the original CN of the g-C3N4. When the Ru atom substitute the nitrogen atom or carbon atom at the N3 site or C3 site, the atom charge are 1.27 e and 1.21 e, respectively, the Ru atom performs a similar function to the Ni atom, which act as electron donor. In summary, both the electron differential density (Fig. 8) and atom charge states (Table 2) reveal that metals Ni and Ru are the best electron contributors, which is also the reason to effectively regulate the band structure and photochemical properties of the photocatalyst g-C3N4. Fig. 9 depicts the band structure and the PDOS of the Ni, Ru doping monolayer g-C3N4(001). The results show that the band gaps of Ni-g-C3N4 (001), Ru-g-C3N4 (001) and pure g-C3N4 (001) are 0.164 eV, 0.260 eV and 1.175 eV, respectively. It can be seen that the doping of metal elements Ni and Ru can reduce the band gap width of the semiconductor catalyst g-C3N4, which can improve the photocatalytic performance of the catalyst g-C3N4. The PDOS of monolayer g-C3N4 (001) doped with Ni and Ru is depicted in Fig. 9(b) and 9(d). It can be inferred that the doping of Ni and Ru electronic orbitals may lead to the decrease of the band gap of g-C3N4, which also suggests that the metals Ni and Ru have an effective regulatory effect on the band structure of g-C3N4. As shown in the PDOS spectra, the Ni-3d electron orbitals favor the orbital hybridization of g-C3N4 at the energy level of −2.0 eV∼2.0 eV, and the Ni-4p, 4 s electron orbitals correspond to the −2.0 eV∼0 eV, the electronic orbitals of Ru-3d, Ru-4p, and 4 s at the energy level of −2.0 eV∼2.0 eV favor orbital hybridization. The above results indicates although metal Ni and Ru act as the electron donor, the band gap reduction also have the close relationship with the electronic orbit modification effect of Ni, Ru in g-C3N4, the rules are similar to the effect of non-metals B and P above. The optical absorption of three photocatalysts, g-C3N4 (001), Ni-g-C3N4 (001) and Ru-g-C3N4 (001), is shown in Fig. 10 . It can be observed that g-C3N4 and Ni, Ru doping g-C3N4 exhibit spectral absorption peaks in the wavelength range of 250 nm to 300 nm, and the absorption peaks of Ni-doped g-C3N4 are the strongest. For pure g-C3N4, the optical absorption intensity is almost zero at wavelengths greater than 520 nm, whereas Ni and Ru doped g-C3N4 still maintains good absorption for longer wavelengths. For example, the photocatalyst Ru-g-C3N4(001) it still has a certain response ability even the wavelength greater than 1000 nm. In conclusion, the metal Ni, Ru is a good modifier, which have a good ability to regulate the photoresponse of g-C3N4. In addition, in the field of metal catalysis, Ru metal has a good catalytic effect (especially in the field of catalytic ammonia borane hydrolysis/alcoholysis). Therefore, Ru metal has broad application potential in coupled photocatalysis and metal catalysis in the future. 3.3 Design of high efficiency hydrogen production system from catalytic ammonia borane Ammonia borane (NH3BH3, AB) is the most promising solid-state hydrogen storage material due to its high hydrogen content and non-toxic environment. In addition, ammonia borane can produce hydrogen by hydrolysis/alcoholysis at room temperature under the action of suitable catalyst. Therefore, the design of high performance catalyst and hydrogen production system is very important in the industrial application of ammonia borane hydrogen production technology. Fig. 11 depict the molecular structures(NH3BH3, H2O, CH3OH) and electron differential density in the hydrogen-producing reaction of catalytic AB. As the Fig. 11 shown, the AB molecule contains NH bonds, B-H bonds and B-N bonds, in the NH bond, the outer electrons of the H atom are moving towards N, which make hydrogen atoms exhibit electrically positive, while in the B-H bonds, the outer electrons of the N atom are moving towards H, and the H of the -BH3 exhibit electrically negative, the electrically positive H of the -NH3 combines with the electrically negative H of the -BH3 to form a double hydrogen bond, which affects the macroscopic physical and chemical properties of AB, for example, the state is solid at ambient temperature, easy to release hydrogen. The B-N bond in AB molecule is formed by covalent bonding of lone pair electrons on nitrogen atoms to empty orbitals on boron atoms. In the CH3OH and H2O molecule, C, H and O atoms form stable covalent bonds by sharing electron pairs, and formed stable covalent bonds CH bonds, HO bonds and CO bond, respectively. Compared with the HO bonds of the CH3OH and H2O, the B-H bond of the NH3BH3 is easily break to release H2. For the purpose of clarifying the hydrogen-producing reaction of AB in g-C3N4 based catalyst, the adsorption performance of molecule NH3BH3, CH3OH and H2O adsorbed on the B-g-C3N4 are investigated via DFT. Fig. 12 depict the ammonia borane, methanol and water molecule adsorbed on the B-g-C3N4 and their adsorption energy, the results shown that the adsorption energy of molecule NH3BH3, CH3OH and H2O adsorbed on the B-g-C3N4 are −1.562 eV, −1.392 eV and −1.443 eV, respectively. The results indicates the process of molecule NH3BH3, CH3OH and H2O adsorbed on the B-g-C3N4 are exothermic process, the adsorption energy of AB molecule adsorbed on the active carrier B-g-C3N4 is greater than CH3OH and H2O molecule. The high adsorption energy means that the molecules are easily adsorbed. ​As the result shown, AB will preferentially adsorb on B-g-C3N4 among the above three molecules, which indicate that AB molecules are preferentially adsorbed and activated in the hydrolysis and alcoholysis reaction systems, increasing the adsorption energy of CH3OH and H2O on B-g-C3N4-based catalysts is beneficial to the hydrogen production of AB. In addition, the adsorption energies of B-g-C3N4 for CH3OH and H2O are almost equal, it means that the reason for the difference in the reaction rates of AB hydrolysis and alcoholysis is not the adsorbability of the molecules on the catalyst, which may be due to their different reaction kinetics. In the catalytic AB hydrolysis or alcoholysis reaction system, the variation of HO bond strength can qualitatively reflect the efficiency of AB alcoholysis for hydrogen production due to the rate-determining step of the AB hydrolysis or alcoholysis is OH bond cleavage of water or methanol. In the study, OH bond fracture is studied by choosing a representative hydrogen production by AB alcoholysis. In order to investigate the doping effect on the catalytic AB alcoholysis for hydrogen production, the effect of Ru metal doped g-C3N4 on HO bond of CH3OH are studied, the optimization model are shown in Fig. 13 . The difficulty of OH bond breaking in CH3OH molecules on catalysts g-C3N4 and Ru@g-C3N4 are calculated, respectively. The calculation result shows when the OH bond breaking on the pure g-C3N4(001), the energy barrier to be overcome in this process is 4.551 eV, while the energy barrier to be overcome in the process of OH bond breaking on the Ru@g-C3N4(001) is 1.530 eV. Therefore, Ru metal doped g-C3N4 is conducive to OH fracture in CH3OH, and it is beneficial to the hydrogen-producing reaction of AB alcoholysis. According to the above research results, the highly efficient functional catalyst for hydrogen production of AB in liquid phase can be prepared successfully. The precious metal Ru and the transition metal Ni have a large modification and improvement effect on the catalytic performance of the photocatalyst g-C3N4. Meanwhile, Ru and Ni have good catalytic activity for hydrolyzing or alcohololysis of AB to produce hydrogen [23,24]. Therefore, the catalytic activity of the photocatalyst g-C3N4 can be enhanced by the co-doping of Ru and Ni with g-C3N4, and the synergistic action of bimetal RuNi can also improve the metal catalytic hydrogen production of AB. Besides, the doping modification of non-metal B and P is also beneficial to improve the catalytic performance of the photocatalyst g-C3N4, in which the B element has more excellent performance. The construction and design of a new bifunctional catalyst(photocatalysis and metal catalysis) RuNiB@g-C3N4 is an efficient route in catalyze the liquid phase AB for hydrogen production. In addition, the narrow band always accompanied by a high recombination rate of the photogenerated carriers, in order to avoid the recombination of photogenerated electrons-holes, the metal Ru or Ni can be deposited on the surface of the catalyst to act as the transfer medium for photogenerated electrons, which is beneficial to improve the utilization rate of photogenerated electrons in the photocatalyst and improve the photocatalytic efficiency. The diagram of photoelectron transfer of photocatalyst RuNiB@g-C3N4 can be shown in Fig. 14 . 4 Conclusion In the study, the modification methods of photochemical properties of semiconductor photocatalyst g-C3N4 are investigated, and mainly focus on the influence of doping of metal (Ru, Ni) and nonmetal (B, P) elements on the photoresponse of g-C3N4 and their modification mechanism. For the requirement of efficiently catalytic AB in liquid phase for hydrogen production, the high-performance bifunctional catalyst are designed, which are the dual function of photocatalysis and metal catalysis to improve the hydrogen production efficiency of AB. ​The conclusions of the related studies are given below: (1) The non-metals B, P have an efficient regulatory effect on the band structure of g-C3N4, which make the band gap of the clean monolayer g-C3N4(001) decrease from 1.175 eV to 0.261 eV and 0.671 eV, respectively, and B have the better modification effect compared with the P element. The B-2p and B-2 s electron orbitals are favorable for the orbital hybridization of g-C3N4 at the energy levels from 0 eV to 1.17 eV, and the P-2p and P-2 s electron orbitals are favorable for the orbital hybridization of g-C3N4 at the energy levels from 0 eV to 1.17 eV. (2) Doping with metallic Ni and Ru effectively reduces the band gap width of the semiconductor catalysts g-C3N4, the band gap of the Ni-g-C3N4(001) and Ru-g-C3N4(001) are reduced to 0.164 eV and 0.260 eV, respectively. Compared with the function of metal Ni and Ru act as the electron donor the non-metallic doping element B and P also act as the electron donor, and the band gap reduction have the close relationship with the electronic orbit modification effect of Ni, Ru in g-C3N4. (3) Ru metal doped g-C3N4 is conducive to OH fracture in CH3OH(reduced from 4.551 eV to 1.530 eV), which is beneficial to the hydrogen-producing reaction of AB alcoholysis. The construction of a novel bifunctional catalyst (photocatalysis and metal catalysis) RuNiB@g-C3N4 is an efficient route in improving hydrogen production efficiency form AB.The process of molecule NH3BH3, CH3OH and H2O adsorbed on the B-g-C3N4 are exothermic process, the adsorption energy are −1.562 eV, −1.392 eV and −1.443 eV, respectively. Among the three molecules, AB, CH3OH and H2O, AB is preferentially adsorbed on the catalyst B-g-C3N4, the difference in the reaction rates of AB hydrolysis and alcoholysis is not the adsorbability of the AB molecules on the catalyst, the adsorbability of the CH3OH, H2O molecules and reaction kinetics play the decisive role. coredata.dc:description: In the study, based on the purpose of efficient catalytic AB for hydrogen production, the photochemical properties influence of metal(Ru, Ni) and nonmetal(B,P) elements doping on the g-C3N4 are studied systematacially. The design method of high performance bifunctional catalyst of photocatalysis and metal catalysis are provided. The results have proved that both non-metals B, P and metal Ru, Ni have an efficient regulatory effect on the band structure of g-C3N4, which make the band gap of the clean monolayer g-C3N4(001) decrease from 1.175 eV to 0.261eV(B-g-C3N4(001)) and 0.671eV(P-g-C3N4(001)), 0.164 eV(Ni-g-C3N4(001)) and 0.260 eV(Ru-g-C3N4(001)), respectively. B element have the better modification effect compared with the P element. The reduction of band gap is attributed to the electronic orbit modification effect of impurity element B, P, Ni, Ru in g-C3N4. Ru metal doped g-C3N4 is reduces the barrier of OH bond breakage of CH3OH(reduced from 4.551 eV to 1.530 eV), which is beneficial to the hydrogen-producing reaction of AB alcoholysis. The construction and design of a new bifunctional catalyst(photocatalysis and metal catalysis) RuNiB@g-C3N4 is an efficient route in catalyze AB for hydrogen production. The process of molecule NH3BH3, CH3OH and H2O adsorbed on the B-g-C3N4 are exothermic process, the adsorption energy are -1.562 eV, -1.392 eV and -1.443 eV, respectively. AB is preferentially adsorbed on the B-g-C3N4 catalyst, increasing the adsorption energy of CH3OH and H2O on B-g-C3N4-based catalysts is beneficial to the hydrogen production from AB. The study provides a theoretical method for the research on the technology of the coupling of metal catalysis/photocatalysis ammonia borane to produce hydrogen.
coredata.dc:title: The performance improvement method of g-C3N4 based catalyst for hydrogen production from ammonia borane: A DFT investigation
